individual_metadata.synopsis: Halsin's default dialogue at camp once he's joined you as a follower. You can ask how he's faring in your company, as well as glean some details about your next quest. Halsin is avuncular and scholarly, but his mood grows darker whenever he speaks of Moonrise Towers and the curse that has shrouded it.Once Thaniel, the spirit of the land, has been rescued and brought to camp, a new branch will unlock where Halsin can explain that Thaniel's heart is missing, and it needs to be retrieved in order for the Shadow curse to be lifted. Halsin can be recruited as a companion 11from then on.
individual_metadata.how_to_trigger: Speak to Halsin after he's joined you as a camp follower (progress through the Saving the Grove quest in Act One or add Halsin as a follower via camp debug book)

12.speaker: Player
12.text: I have to ask - how do you know so much about the parasite?

102.speaker: Halsin
102.text: I studied one up close - closer than most would care to be to those things.

149.speaker: Halsin
149.text: A drow attacked me and I defended myself. Afterwards, I was able to examine the tadpole that emerged.

42.speaker: Halsin
42.text: Hideous - but fascinating. Like nothing else in nature, I'm glad to say.

243.speaker: Player
243.text: You've been researching the illithid parasites - is there anything you can tell me?

71.speaker: Halsin
71.text: I've inspected a tadpole up close and seen the effects of them on the Absolute's so-called 'True Souls.'

190.speaker: Halsin
190.text: Powerful, certainly. But clearly arrested by magic, too. The question I just can't answer is who has done this. And why?

52.speaker: Halsin
52.text: There'll be no firm answers until Moonrise Towers, I fear.

123.speaker: Player
123.text: What will happen to the grove now?

169.speaker: Halsin
169.text: It is lost to me - lost to the world. Perhaps there'll be some way to unseal it in the future...

236.speaker: Halsin
236.text: ...perhaps not. I do not know. All I can do for now is to try do some good where I can - try to help you.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: How will the grove fare without you?

221.speaker: Halsin
221.text: Hopefully. I've chosen a successor as First Druid - Francesca of the High Forest. I sent a bird to summon her.

162.speaker: Player
162.text: First and only Druid. What will Francesca even do here?

10.speaker: Halsin
10.text: She can tend to the grove, help it heal. In time, others will join. Perhaps some day I can return.

168.speaker: Halsin
168.text: A fellow druid. I can count on her to tend to the grove in my absence, help it heal.

200.speaker: Halsin
200.text: Precisely! Who indeed? You do not know, and neither do any of the others.
200.context: NodeContext: Turning the player's question around with emphasis - they've inadvertently stumbled upon his reasoning in choosing a successor, which he'll now expand upon,

223.speaker: Player
223.text: There's nobody in the grove you'd choose?

241.speaker: Halsin
241.text: No. At least, not right now.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: What about one of the others? Rath, perhaps?

101.speaker: Halsin
101.text: Rath has promise, but he's not ready yet. The grove needs experience and a strong hand.

14.speaker: Halsin
14.text: I need her to stay focused on her training - the grove will need a skilled healer in my absence.

138.speaker: Halsin
138.text: The grove needs to move beyond the mistakes of the past. What it needs is an unknown quantity; an outsider who can enforce the Oak Father's teachings without bias.

194.speaker: Halsin
194.text: This is why I chose Francesca. She will restore simplicity and purity to the grove in my absence.

208.speaker: Halsin
208.text: Contrary to how some think of us, we druids can play politics when necessary.

49.speaker: Halsin
49.text: Resentment will spring up like mushrooms no matter what I do. You cannot please everyone and you'd be a fool to try.

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Sounds like the grove will be in good hands then.

240.speaker: Player
240.text: This shadow curse you spoke of... surely it can't be that bad.
240.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN only after Halsin has briefed you on the Shadow curse, until you enter the grymforge. QN only shown if the player is in Act 1

211.speaker: Halsin
211.text: It's had the whole region around Moonrise Towers in a chokehold of darkness and despair for years now.

98.speaker: Halsin
98.text: Those who remained are shadow-cursed. If you don't die at their hands, then you become one of them.

177.speaker: Halsin
177.text: We have to get to Moonrise, but the less time we spend in its blighted surrounds, the better.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: I found the stronghold in the Underdark you mentioned - a place called Grymforge.
116.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player has already entered the grymforge but has not yet spoken to Halsin about it. QN only shown if the player is in Act 1

233.speaker: Halsin
233.text: Impressive. Most would quake at the mere thought of delving that far into the Underdark. What did you find?

15.speaker: Player
15.text: I found an elevator - but it leads right into the shadow curse.
15.context: InternalNodeContext: This node if the player clicked the elevator from Grymforge to SCL

114.speaker: Halsin
114.text: That sounds like what you need. But the next part of the journey mightn't be straightforward - or safe.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: Absolute followers - but that's about all.
165.context: InternalNodeContext: This node if the player didn't click the elevator from Grymforge to SCL

18.speaker: Halsin
18.text: Keep looking. If they're present, then it's likely there's a route to Moonrise somewhere.

58.speaker: Halsin
58.text: It may prove impossible to avoid the shadow curse entirely, but if you find any way to limit your exposure, seize it.
58.context: InternalNodeContext: GLO_Halsin_AcknowledgedGrymforge sets whenever the player enquires about the Grymforge and Halsin acknowledges how it may relate to the journey to Moonrise.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: Danger. Are you sure that's the best way to Moonrise?

251.speaker: Halsin
251.text: I'm certain. The Underdark is dangerous, yes, but the alternative is suicide. Be patient and be thorough - the path will reveal itself in time.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: I've got more exploring to do.

155.speaker: Halsin
155.text: Tread carefully. You're on the right track, I'm sure - but there'll still be danger and difficulty before you reach Moonrise.

72.speaker: Player
72.text: What about this secret stronghold in the Underdark? You must know more.
72.context: InternalNodeContext: QN only shown if the player is in Act 1

276.speaker: Halsin
276.text: Precious little, but I'm quite certain it can still be found.

70.speaker: Halsin
70.text: Aradin was convinced there was a hidden entrance in the temple of Selûne - I'd start there.

196.speaker: Halsin
196.text: One of his cohorts, a dwarf called Brian, had a clue on his person. If you find his corpse in the goblins' camp, you may have a start.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Why do you want to go to Moonrise Towers?
3.context: InternalNodeContext: QN only shown if the player is in Act 1

110.speaker: Halsin
110.text: Those illithid creatures threaten the natural order - it's my duty to do what I can to stop them.

2.speaker: Halsin
2.text: There's also the shadow curse - it's an affront and must be cleansed.

121.speaker: Halsin
121.text: I helped overthrow Ketheric Thorm and his Dark Justiciars years ago. But I failed to prevent him from unleashing darkness across the region before he was defeated.

74.speaker: Halsin
74.text: If I can join you and get close to Moonrise, perhaps I can lift this curse just as you find a cure for your infection.

44.speaker: Player
44.text: Seems like you feel responsible for this shadow curse somehow...

174.speaker: Halsin
174.text: Well... there's hardly anyone left to share the responsibility with. Few who witnessed the fall of Moonrise still draw breath.

83.speaker: Halsin
83.text: What Ketheric Thorm unleashed is not something that nature can undo by itself. I must do what I can.

231.speaker: Halsin
231.text: I studied the shadow curse for years. But to truly understand it - and stop it - I must reach its source.

205.speaker: Halsin
205.text: His strength is coming back to him. Soon he'll be able to banish the curse once and for all. Until then, we should do what we can to stop the Absolute.

89.speaker: Halsin
89.text: He's still fighting. The curse hasn't won yet, but he'll need our help if he's to recover.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: Share what you learned of Thaniel's presence in the Shadowfell.

249.speaker: Halsin
249.text: Good - this is what we've been lacking. Now there's a chance we can find Thaniel, and bring him home.

84.speaker: Halsin
84.text: What comes next will prove dangerous. Meet me by the shore outside Last Light - we can do our work there without imperilling others.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: I found a Flaming Fist who escaped the Shadowfell - but he's dead.

229.speaker: Halsin
229.text: Poor soul... but in truth, if I had to choose between death and the Shadowfell, I'd choose death.

109.speaker: Halsin
109.text: Perhaps there's still a way to learn something from him - the dead can't deny their knowledge, if asked the right question.

256.speaker: Player
256.text: There's a Flaming Fist recuperating in Last Light. Seems he escaped from the curse - and he spoke of a boy called Thaniel.

127.speaker: Halsin
127.text: A survivor? Silvanus blesses us - this could be just the person we need to speak to.

225.speaker: Halsin
225.text: Thaniel is no ordinary child - he is the very spirit of this land. If this Fist knows where he is, then perhaps we can save him... save everything.

224.speaker: Halsin
224.text: I will go to see him at once. Join me when you can.

216.speaker: Player
216.text: There's a Flaming Fist at Last Light. The curse has left him insensible, but he's muttering about a boy called Thaniel.

185.speaker: Halsin
185.text: He is...? Then I must see him. Insensible or not, he knows something.

189.speaker: Player
189.text: We're in the midst of the shadow curse now. Is there any more you can tell me about how to lift it?
189.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player previously asked how the shadow curse could be lifted while still in Acrt 1. This question is available once they're in Act 2 and indicates there may be new info via the different question text.

50.speaker: Halsin
50.text: We must find Thaniel. He is the embodiment of nature's power, but... but he is just a child. A child who has been trapped in this place for a hundred years.

105.speaker: Halsin
105.text: But if we can find him, we can break the curse. If you learn anything of the Shadowfell, or of a boy with the forest in his eyes, find me at once.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: What should I look for, exactly?

153.speaker: Halsin
153.text: I can't be exact, unfortunately. Time and the shadow curse won't have been kind to any traces that would have been left behind.

255.speaker: Halsin
255.text: A living witness is unlikely, I'll admit. But perhaps there'll be an unliving witness, or some lingering echo of what we seek.

120.speaker: Halsin
120.text: Don't worry - if you find something, you will know it.

219.speaker: Player
219.text: I'll see what I can find out.

254.speaker: Halsin
254.text: Oak Father shield you, my friend.

133.speaker: Halsin
133.text: This land is more than just soil and rock, root and leaf... it is a living being, in the form of a young fey boy, with the forest itself in his eyes. His name is Thaniel - I've met him, in my meditations.

261.speaker: Halsin
261.text: ...But since the curse was unleashed, I have not felt his presence. He is its prisoner, I fear. And as long as he remains so, his domain will lie in darkness.

245.speaker: Halsin
245.text: Perhaps, but we'll need to get closer before I can put my theory into practice.

199.speaker: Halsin
199.text: Put it from your mind for now. Once we near the curse - then there will be more to be said.

277.speaker: Player
277.text: Do you know how the shadow curse can be stopped?

183.speaker: Player
183.text: Come, I need you by my side out there.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: Is that why you went with Aradin? You thought he might find this route to Moonrise?
79.context: InternalNodeContext: QN only shown if the player is in Act 1

253.speaker: Halsin
253.text: Precisely. Then perhaps I could have done something about both the shadow curse and ceremorphosis aberrations.

76.speaker: Halsin
76.text: But in my eagerness, I put far too much faith in the abilities of Aradin and his band. We didn't even get close.

60.speaker: Halsin
60.text: One of those who died had a clue that was supposed to help us find the hidden entrance to the Underdark.

278.speaker: Halsin
278.text: A dwarf called Brian, I believe. Though there's no guarantee that the goblins left him recognisable.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: It can't have been easy, surrendering your title. Won't you miss being First Druid?

48.speaker: Halsin
48.text: Miss it? Oh dear no. It's a terrible burden; takes you away from nature and forces you to deal with others' problems and personalities.

267.speaker: Halsin
267.text: Be wary of anyone who actually wants such a role, I say. Likely they don't understand it, or they have ill intent.

29.speaker: Halsin
29.text: I'm just glad to be out here amidst the Oak Father's creations.

163.speaker: Player
163.text: At the celebration with the tieflings before - I hope I didn't come over too strong. Got caught up in the moment.
163.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN only if the player flirted with Halsin during CAMP_GoblinHuntCelebration_Halsin. Availabler for WLD_Main_A only

26.speaker: Player
26.text: Still feeling at home here with us? The surroundings are less bucolic, I understand...

270.speaker: Player
270.text: These lands must bring back bad memories for you. I hope you're still faring all right with us.

157.speaker: Player
157.text: You're still faring well at camp, I hope?

38.speaker: Player
38.text: How're you faring out here at the camp?

53.speaker: Halsin
53.text: I'd rather the shadow curse didn't linger just beyond the campfire... but your company more than makes up for it.

195.speaker: Halsin
195.text: It's not easy, seeing the ravages of the shadow curse... but your camp is a most welcome solace.
195.context: NodeContext: Bittersweet. Tough times but good company.

212.speaker: Halsin
212.text: You've shared your fire with me, your company. A small pocket of light against the darkness, but one I couldn't do without. Thank you.

266.speaker: Halsin
266.text: I can only imagine what fate would I have met without you -rotting in the goblins' cells? Being sealed away by the Rite of Thorns for all eternity?

85.speaker: Halsin
85.text: I wish I could have found another fate for the Grove, but I appreciate all you have done for me nonetheless.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Maybe you could show your appreciation another way.

239.speaker: Halsin
239.text: I can think of a thing or two... but the curse grips my mind for now, and I would loathe to give you only part of my attention.
239.context: NodeContext: Hint of flirtation, followed by a small weary sigh before 'but the curse' (duty still calls)

0.speaker: Halsin
0.text: Perhaps if I manage to break the curse... perhaps then I can show you just how grateful I am.

227.speaker: Player
227.text: No words needed - I understand how you feel.

230.speaker: Halsin
230.text: ...Forgive me. Sometimes I forget myself, gazing on the beauty of nature's creations.
230.context: NodeContext: Lost his train of thought, absorbed by the sight of the player

176.speaker: Halsin
176.text: You're too modest by far. What fate would I have met without you? Rotting in the goblins' cells? Dying against an onslaught on the Grove?

139.speaker: Halsin
139.text: More good has been done since I met you than in a hundred years before. Words cannot express my gratitude.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: Perhaps I could share more than a camp fire and some company...

156.speaker: Halsin
156.text: I can think of a thing or two... but in truth, it is for the best that the curse consumes my thoughts for now. This is the best chance I've had in a century - I cannot squander it.
156.context: NodeContext: Hint of flirtation, followed by a small weary sigh before 'but in truth' (duty still calls)

56.speaker: Halsin
56.text: But... if I succeed, if I break the curse, then perhaps there will be time for myself again. And for others.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Don't get too sentimental - I had need of a guide in order to survive this curse.

36.speaker: Halsin
36.text: Prudent. But I hope we won't have to contend with the perils of the curse for long. There's more to living than just survival. Much more.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: I'm glad. But let's keep focused at the same time.

43.speaker: Halsin
43.text: With such stimulating company? Never better.

252.speaker: Halsin
252.text: Wonderfully! If I'm honest, the grove was too comfortable for my tastes; I felt removed from nature.

264.speaker: Halsin
264.text: I'll miss my books, but I can find all the wisdom they contain out here, first-hand.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Well if there's anything I can do to make you less comfortable, let me know.

248.speaker: Halsin
248.text: I'm sure something will come to me, given time.

143.speaker: Player
143.text: At the celebration before - I may have came over too strong perhaps. Got caught up in the moment.
143.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN only if the player flirted with Halsin during CAMP_GoblinHuntCelebration_Halsin

66.speaker: Halsin
66.text: There are few things that are too strong for me. And cast those regrets aside; you did not get caught up in the moment - you seized it.

94.speaker: Halsin
94.text: In other circumstances, I would have done the same.

34.speaker: Halsin
34.text: Perhaps... but best to not dwell on nights past. There are plenty more yet to come.
34.context: NodeContext: Not disinterested in the player

259.speaker: Player
259.text: I'm glad I didn't leave a bad impression then.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: Honestly? Let's just forget it ever happened.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: You'll find plenty of books before long. I keep coming across them everywhere.

147.speaker: Halsin
147.text: Is that so? Well, nature does abhor waste... I will keep watch, thank you. I had a feeling time in your company would prove fruitful.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: I think I might be sick beyond the tadpole... I'm getting worried.

272.speaker: Halsin
272.text: Everything in your mind has been destroyed, from what I gathered. And from the path I see you on, you are doing well at picking up the pieces.

151.speaker: Halsin
151.text: I am here to be your ear, as you bear your burdens, and the arms that protect you, if you can shoulder them no more.

47.speaker: Halsin
47.text: I believe you when you tell me that your symptoms do not wholly align with the makings of the parasite. But until we remove it, I doubt we will be able to isolate the rest of your troubles.

217.speaker: Player
217.text: You're right. I'll try to keep it together.

39.speaker: Halsin
39.text: Good lad. You're tougher than Blackwood.

141.speaker: Player
141.text: Sleepwalking... hallucinating creatures... the temptations... I could lose myself before I make it to a cure.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: Black outs, fainting spells. I'm losing new memories every day...

11.speaker: Halsin
11.text: The Oak Father must have blessed you to make it this far, or another eye above.

269.speaker: Halsin
269.text: If I had my fleet of druids and a month of hard research, perhaps I could help. But I'm no savant, for now I can only guarantee a cure for ceremorphosis.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: Try as I may, I cannot stop thinking about death.

90.speaker: Halsin
90.text: A haunting has come upon you, but the first step is this admission you have now made. You will not walk alone into this night, remember that.

24.speaker: Halsin
24.text: We need to find Oliver and get him to return to Thaniel. Otherwise this curse will never be lifted.

40.speaker: Halsin
40.text: I swear I can already feel a change in the air - like the curse itself knows its time is short.
40.context: NodeContext: Content/savouring the moment - his mission has been a success

93.speaker: Halsin
93.text: Thaniel is resting - but it's no easy slumber. I discovered what's wrong with him.

96.speaker: Halsin
96.text: The shadows rended him in two when they bore him away to the Shadowfell. Half of his essence remained here, amidst the curse.

63.speaker: Halsin
63.text: What stayed behind would have been the strongest part of him, but after all these years left in darkness, corruption must have taken hold.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: Tell me how I can help.

31.speaker: Halsin
31.text: It's both simple and not - we need to find Thaniel's missing half, and make him whole again.

13.speaker: Halsin
13.text: Perhaps - if we can find Thaniel's lost half, and make him whole again.

152.speaker: Halsin
152.text: Only, the missing half may not come willingly. The curse will have sunk its tendrils deep, twisting Thaniel's essence into something... else.

209.speaker: Player
209.text: Any ideas on how to find this missing half?

161.speaker: Player
161.text: You're sending me to look for a needle in a haystack. In the dark.

148.speaker: Halsin
148.text: No matter how it's been twisted by the shadows, it is still part of Thaniel's essence - it will resemble him somehow, and may show signs of his power.

107.speaker: Halsin
107.text: Look for signs of life in the darkness. Wildflowers, where everything else is dead. The curse cannot subdue the power Thaniel bears. Not entirely.
107.context: NodeContext: Grave. They'll have to effectively kill a child to save a child.

136.speaker: Halsin
136.text: In fact, I saw just the sort before, not long after we first came within reach of the shadow curse. Fool that I am, I did not grasp their significance at the time.
136.context: NodeContext: Moment of realisation. Kicking himself a bit for not putting 2 + 2 together earlier

118.speaker: Halsin
118.text: There is a ruin, some way outside of Last Light. I caught a glimpse of fresh blooms there, but did not investigate further. I shall mark it upon your map.
118.context: NodeContext: Eager/determined. They have a promising lead

265.speaker: Player
265.text: All right, leave it to me.

111.speaker: Halsin
111.text: This doesn't have to be your burden alone. Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side.

192.speaker: Halsin
192.text: If you want me, I'm yours. Against the curse, against the Absolute - anything. Just say the word.

132.speaker: Halsin
132.text: Seems your ranks are quite packed. If some space frees up, I'll be ready for you.

131.speaker: Halsin
131.text: Good. Now our roots can deepen - together.

247.speaker: Player
247.text: I met a sort of shadow child before - a little boy named Oliver. Around Thaniel's age.

257.speaker: Player
257.text: I met a shadow child named Oliver, resembling Thaniel - but he's dead now.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: I'll see what I can do, but no promises.

158.speaker: Halsin
158.text: Let me help you then. Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side.

154.speaker: Player
154.text: Once Thaniel's essence is found, what then?

51.speaker: Halsin
51.text: In truth, I'm not sure. This is beyond all reckoning. It's still part of Thaniel, deep down, but it may not recognise that, or want to recognise that.

172.speaker: Halsin
172.text: Perhaps it can be reasoned with, but I'm not hopeful. Reason is not something that thrives amidst the shadow curse.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: I met a sort of shadow child before - a little boy named Oliver. Around Thaniel's age.

126.speaker: Halsin
126.text: And you saw this boy yourself? That can't be a coincidence - but we need to be sure.

213.speaker: Halsin
213.text: And I truly mean we, if you wish. Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side.

226.speaker: Player
226.text: I met a shadow child named Oliver, resembling Thaniel - but he's dead now.

134.speaker: Halsin
134.text: Perhaps not - if he truly is a part of Thaniel, then he is beyond life and death. More likely he's just hiding. We should return to where you saw him.

21.speaker: Halsin
21.text: I knew something was wrong when he didn't wake up, but now I'm even more certain.

80.speaker: Halsin
80.text: By now, we should have seen some small glimmer of Thaniel's power - a sign that the land is healing. New growth, flowers in bloom. But there has been nothing.

97.speaker: Halsin
97.text: Thaniel rests well. He's healing very rapidly, now that Oliver has returned to him.
97.context: NodeContext: Content/savouring the moment - his mission has been a success

274.speaker: Halsin
274.text: I knew I could put my faith in you. If only we had met sooner.

242.speaker: Player
242.text: So when will the curse actually be lifted?

46.speaker: Halsin
46.text: I can't say for certain, but we'll see it come to pass long before this place recedes behind us. Don't worry - all is at hand. We can depart whenever you're ready.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: What happened to Oliver, exactly? Did Thaniel... absorb him?

25.speaker: Halsin
25.text: No more than my right hand can absorb my left. Oliver is helping Thaniel to recover; they both lie dormant, like trees awaiting spring.

37.speaker: Halsin
37.text: Once the curse is lifted, they can stand as one or as a pair. Whatever they wish.

282.speaker: Halsin
282.text: I hope they will remain as a pair. It would be good for them both to have a friend, once I'm gone.
282.context: NodeContext: A little bittersweet. The kids are growing up.

173.speaker: Halsin
173.text: Still, I would like to return here some day. See Thaniel and Oliver again - in my meditations, or perhaps in person, if the Oak Father wills it. I hope he does.

281.speaker: Player
281.text: I hope you've no more requests - I need to take care of my own problems.

124.speaker: Halsin
124.text: No, my friend. The only thing I ask of you is to allow me by your side on the road ahead. I still owe you a debt, and I intend to pay.

218.speaker: Player
218.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

250.speaker: Halsin
250.text: I have. But perhaps there is more that I want...
250.context: NodeContext: A little smoldering intensity/longing in the second line. Like he's seeing the player with new, romantic eyes.

181.speaker: Halsin
181.text: Anyway, once the curse is lifted, nature can take its course without me. I belong at your side.

198.speaker: Halsin
198.text: And I'm glad to be had - glad to be with you, I mean.
198.context: NodeContext: Slight pause in the middle to correct his phrasing for any perceived innuendo

197.speaker: Player
197.text: This 'more' that you want. What is it?

159.speaker: Halsin
159.text: Not what. Who. But all in due course.

234.speaker: Player
234.text: You flirting with me, big man? Why not spare the talk and get straight to the sweaty part?

178.speaker: Halsin
178.text: You are not bound by social niceties, I see. I like that. Perhaps I can show you just how much, another time.
178.context: NodeContext: Flirty. Enjoying the player's direct approach.

164.speaker: Player
164.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

273.speaker: Player
273.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

222.speaker: Player
222.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

69.speaker: Halsin
69.text: Indeed, but we cannot yet say the same for you. I promised I would help you, and I intend to keep that promise, however I can.

187.speaker: Halsin
187.text: Who knows what awaits us in the city and beyond, but we shall face whatever may come as staunch allies and unwavering friends.

112.speaker: Halsin
112.text: And I am glad to be at your side. I just hope an old bear can prove to be of some service to you.

125.speaker: Halsin
125.text: Perhaps so, or perhaps not. I had wondered if I had detected something else once... but I must have been mistaken - my admiration for you, conflated with other feelings.
125.context: NodeContext: A little conflicted/betraying some romantic longing

64.speaker: Halsin
64.text: But friendship is no consolation trophy. I cherish the bond we have forged. Whether it should grow into something else is not for me to predict.
64.context: NodeContext: A little conflicted/betraying some romantic longing

35.speaker: Player
35.text: Just try to make yourself useful.

144.speaker: Halsin
144.context: NodeContext: Stoic in the face of the player's dismissiveness

113.speaker: Player
113.text: What now? You've got what you wanted, after all.

117.speaker: Halsin
117.text: The shadow curse is upon us. As foul as I remember it - perhaps even worse.
117.context: NodeContext: Troubled/determined. Finally in the Shadow-cursed lands after hearing about it for some time.

167.speaker: Halsin
167.text: But with the Oak Father's blessing, we may soon see it banished from these lands.
167.context: NodeContext: Troubled/determined. Finally in the Shadow-cursed lands after hearing about it for some time.

202.speaker: Halsin
202.text: Bittersweet, that we had to leave Thaniel's realm so soon, after all that was done to save it. But it shall thrive in our absence, and now Baldur's Gate awaits.
202.context: NodeContext: Slight twinge of reject that they couldn't stop and smell the roses (this is in a camp close to Baldur's Gate, some time after they left the formerly-shadow-cursed lands).

220.speaker: Halsin
220.text: Thaniel still suffers. There'll be no improvement until his essence is restored, I fear.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: I met a sort of shadow child before - a little boy named Oliver. Around Thaniel's age.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: I met a shadow child named Oliver, resembling Thaniel - but he's dead now.
